case_name: successor-in-interest of Cursetjee Cowasjee Banajee v. Collector of Bombay Suburban District

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 560 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATTE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 560 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated February 23, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 50 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 23, 1961, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No,. 50 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SHAH J. on April 3, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 3. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-

facts.text: Agreement called Cowl dated October 2, 1830 conferred farm rights on Banajee in seven villages: Mogra, Wasivre, Bandivli, Majas, Part Pahadi, Goregaon, Poisar.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement called Cowl dated October 2, 1830 the Principal Collector of Konkan companyferred on behalf of the East India Company farm rights upon one Cursetjee Cowasjee Banajee-hereinafter called Banajee-in seven villages  1  Mogra,  2  Wasivre,  3  Bandivli  4  Majas  5  Part Pahadi,  6  Goregaon and  7  Poisar

facts.text: Two letters dated October 17, 1835 and July 17, 1841 modified the cowl requiring Banajee to pay Rs. 2,708/7/- per annum.

anchor.surface_text: on terms and companyditions set out therein By two letters dated October 17, 1835 and July 17, 1841 the original companyl was modified and Banajee was required to pay an amount to the East India Company of Rs. 2,708/7/- per annum

facts.text: Banajee constructed extensive salt works and expended Rs. 2 lakhs improving the villages.

anchor.surface_text: in companysideration of the benefits companyferred upon him by the said companyl. Banajee companystructed extensive salt works in the villages and expended Rs. 2/- lakhs

facts.text: On September 22, 1847 East India Company granted seven villages to Banajee freed from cowl and land revenue liability in consideration of improvements and Rs. 30,000 paid.

anchor.surface_text: On September 22, 1847 the East India Company granted to Banajee the seven villages on certain terms, freed from the companyenants of the companyl, and also from liability to pay assessment on land revenue in companysideration of the amount spent by him for improving the villages, and an amount of Rs. 30,000/- paid

facts.text: Villages held by successors of Banajee without payment of land revenue till 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The villages were held and enjoyed by the successors of Banajee under the terms of the grant without payment of land revenue till the year. 1952.

facts.text: Salsette Estates Land Revenue Exemption Abolition Act, XLVII of 1951 assented by President on January 4, 1952, brought into force March 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature of the Bombay State enacted the Salsette Estates  Land Revenue Exemption Abolition  Act, XLVII of 1951  hereinafter called the Act  which received the assent of the President on January 4, 1952 and was brought into force on March 1, 1952.

facts.text: Collector of Bombay Suburban District by letter dated February 28, 1952 informed appellant that from March 1, 1952 waste lands vest in Government per Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Bombay Suburban District by his letter dated February 28, 1952 informed the appellant-who is the successor-in-interest of Banajee under the grant that with effect from March 1, 1952 as provided by s. 4 -of the Act all waste lands

facts.text: Appellant by letter dated March 5, 1952 claimed absolute ownership under 1847 indenture, Act does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated March 5, 1952 the appellant submitted that the seven villages were held as absolute owner under and by virtue of the indenture of companyveyance dated September 22, 1847

facts.text: Collector by letter dated June 25, 1952 informed Act applicable to villages.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated June 25, 1952 the Collector informed the appellant that the provisions of the Act were applicable to the seven villages

facts.text: Appellant commenced Suit No. 52 of 1953 on November 28, 1952 in Bombay High Court for declaration Act does not apply and injunction.

anchor.surface_text: On November 28, 1952 the appellant companymenced an action against the State of Bombay  which was numbered Suit No. 52 of 1953  in the High Court of judicature at Bombay

facts.text: State contended appellant not absolute owner, Act applies.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay by its written statement companytended that the appellant was number the absolute owner of the said seven villages, that the Act applied to those villages

facts.text: Trial Judge K. Desai, J. held indenture not lease but farm right, villages estate under s.2(b) of Act.

anchor.surface_text: K. Desai,.T., who heard the suit held that the indenture dated September 22, 1847 was number a lease, but it companyld be regarded as a grant of a farm of the right to recover revenue

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court held villages held under agreement s.2(d), estate under s.2(b), exemption abolished, not saved by s.3(3).

anchor.surface_text: In appeal a Division Bench of the High Court held that the indenture dated September 22, 1847 created a right number of the nature of a lease or farm but the villages were held under an agreement from the State Government within the meaning of s. 2  d  of the Act

facts.text: Appellant abandoned challenge to validity of Act under Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 after Constitution Fourth Amendment Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had initially challenged the validity of the Act as infringing the fundamental rights under Arts. 19  1   f  and 31 of the Constitution but this plea was abandoned after the enactment of the Constitution Fourth Amendment Act, 1955.

facts.text: Seven villages included in Schedule to the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By sub-s.  2  of s. 1 the Act extends to the villages specified in the Schedule to the Act and the seven villages- granted to Banajee are included in the Schedule.

facts.text: Supreme Court held villages not held under lease or farm but under agreement per s.2(d).

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the Trial Court and the High Court that the villages were held by Banajee under an agreement with the East India Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court held exemption not saved by s.3(3) as it excludes estate-holder.

anchor.surface_text: By express provision the estate-holder is excluded from the benefit of sub-s.  3 . The intention of the Legislature is clear it is to withdraw the exemption in favour of the estate-holder

facts.text: Appellant is successor-in-interest of Banajee.

anchor.surface_text: informed the appellant-who is the successor-in-interest of Banajee under the grant

facts.text: Act enacted as agrarian reform to abolish intermediaries.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was. enacted as a measure of agrarian reform and formed part of a pattern of legislation undertaken by the State of Bombay to abolish the rights of intermediaries

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court this appeal is preferred by the appellant.

holdings.text: The villages were not held under a lease within the meaning of s.2(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion of the trial Court and the High Court that the villages were number held under a lease within the meaning of s.2  d  of Act 47 of 1951 must be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grant confers ownership rights including appropriation of rents and profits, not a demise of right to enjoy land for consideration with reserved right to terminate.

holdings.text: The indenture is not of the nature of a farm within the meaning of s.2(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is the indenture of the nature of a farm within the meaning of that clause. The Island of Salsette in which the seven villages are situate was taken over in 1774

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from historical farms where grantee accountable for revenue collection; 1847 indenture discharged prior cowl obligations without reserving revenue accountability or agency.

holdings.text: The villages were held under an agreement with the East India Company within the meaning of s.2(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the Trial Court and the High Court that the villages were held by Banajee under an agreement with the East India Company. By the indenture the villages were granted to Banajee, and he was freed from liability to pay assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption from land revenue granted subject to covenants and conditions (tenant rights, dewasthans, rent if demanded, no innovations) constituting agreement under which estate held from State.

holdings.text: The villages constitute an estate within the meaning of s.2(b) of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Villages specified in Schedule and held under cowl (agreement per s.2(d)); both definitional conditions fulfilled.

holdings.text: The exemption from payment of land revenue is not saved by s.3(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By express provision the estate-holder is excluded from the benefit of sub-s.  3 . The intention of the Legislature is clear it is to withdraw the exemption in favour of the estate-holder

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(3) saves exemptions only for persons other than estate-holder under special contract/grant recognized by cowl; expressly excludes estate-holder to abolish intermediaries' exemptions.

anchor.surface_text: By express provision the estate-holder is excluded from the benefit of sub-s. 3 . The intention of the Legislature is clear it is to withdraw the exemption in favour of the estate-holder from payment of land revenue if such right was granted under a cowl, That withdrawal is not to affect the rights of per-sons holding land in an estate under a special contract, or grant which was made or recognized by the terms of the cowl even if the right was to hold the land exempt from the payment of land revenue.

outcome.relief_summary: Villages constitute an 'estate' under the Act; exemption from land revenue for estate-holder not saved by s.3(3); Act applies and exemption abolished

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion of the trial Court and the High Court that the villages were number held under a lease within the meaning of s.2  d  of Act 47 of 1951 must be accepted.

By express provision the estate-holder is excluded from the benefit of sub-s. 3 . The intention of the Legislature is clear it is to withdraw the exemption in favour of the estate-holder from payment of land revenue if such right was granted under a cowl, That withdrawal is not to affect the rights of per-sons holding land in an estate under a special contract, or grant which was made or recognized by the terms of the cowl even if the right was to hold the land exempt from the payment of land revenue.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 states indenture not a farm per s.2(d), directly addressing issue i4

anchor.surface_text: Nor is the indenture of the nature of a farm within the meaning of that clause. The Island of Salsette in which the seven villages are situate was taken over in 1774

But we agree with the Trial Court and the High Court that the villages were held by Banajee under an agreement with the East India Company.

anchor.surface_text: But we agree with the Trial Court and the High Court that the villages were held by Banajee under an agreement with the East India Company. By the indenture the villages were granted to Banajee, and he was freed from liability to pay assessment.
